item.title: Islamic Militants Extend Battle Into Another Iraqi Province
item.description: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria took over three villages in a province next to Anbar.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the site of a bomb attack on Wednesday nearÂ Khulani Square in Baghdad.

item.title: U.N. Panel Assails Vatican Over Sexual Abuse by Priests
item.description: A United Nations report concluded that the church had adopted policies that put its reputation above the interests of children who had been sexually abused.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: India Ink: Cyberabadâs Swagger Returns as Native Son Takes Top Spot at Microsoft
item.description: Hyderabadâs joy in Satya Nadellaâs ascent stems from the misfortunes the Indian tech hub has suffered over the past several years, the author says.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Satya Nadella, the new chief executive of Microsoft.

item.title: Philippine Leader Sounds Alarm on China
item.description: Benigno S. Aquino III, the Philippine president, compared Chinaâs claims to the seas near his country to Hitlerâs demands for Czech land in 1938.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scientists Warn of New Bird Flu Strain in China
item.description: A confirmed death from H10N8 comes as another strain of avian influenza, H7N9, continues to spread in China.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Employees cleaning chickens in a slaughterhouse near Shanghai. While cases of the H7N9 avian influenza continue to surge, researchers have warned of a newer strain, H10N8, that has sickened two women, one fatally after she visited a poultry market.

item.title: Google Reaches Tentative Antitrust Settlement With Europe
item.description: Under the agreement, the firm would pay no fine and there would be no finding of wrongdoing. Such a finding could have limited its future activities.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: JoaquÃ­n Almunia, the European Unionâs competition commissioner, who leaves his post later this year, has made the antitrust settlement with Google a top priority.

item.title: India Ink: Protests over Creation of Telangana Disrupt 1st Day of 2014 Parliament Session
item.description: The Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament, spent a total of nearly one hour in session before protests by various lawmakers forced an early adjournment.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A view of the Indian parliament in New Delhi on Dec. 7, 2012.

item.title: North and South Korea Set Dates for Family Reunions
item.description: The plans for reunions between families separated by a tense border suggest that ties could be improving between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone
item.description: The symbolic importance of the Games for Russia has turned Sochi into a target for Islamic terrorists who have vowed a wave of attacks to advance their goal of an independent caliphate across the North Caucasus.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Locals near the rubble of a house that was destroyed during a counterterrorism operation in Baksan, Russia.

item.title: India Ink: 6th India Art Fair Reports Strong Sales
item.description: The eventâs organizers said a number of exhibitors sold all their offerings, and many local gallery owners said they were pleased by the results.
item.dc:creator: By GAYATRI RANGACHARI SHAH
item.media:description: An installation by Rana Begum that was sold by Jhaveri Contemporary gallery in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: Cases of New Deadly Bird Flu Surge in China, Experts Say
item.description: About 300 cases of H7N9 avian influenza have been confirmed in China, with more appearing every day.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Listening Post: In the Scripted World of Diplomacy, a Burst of Tweets
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and other officials are using Twitter to augment, and even replace, the carefully scripted and vetted language of official statements.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: Anne Frank Toy Found
item.description: The Anne Frank House museum in Amsterdam said that toys given by Anne Frank to a non-Jewish friend shortly before she and her family went into hiding from the Nazis have been recovered.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Tunisia: Raid Kills Assassination Suspect
item.description: The National Guard stormed a suspected militant hide-out after a daylong standoff, killing seven militants, including a suspect in a political assassination last year, the interior minister said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Old Tensions Resurface in Debate Over U.S. Role in Post-2014 Afghanistan
item.description: President Obama is trying to figure out what form a residual force might take after the bulk of American troops leave, or what would happen if no Americans stayed behind.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: President Obama, speaking at a school in Adelphi, Md., met with his top Afghan commanders in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Blocks Several Activists From Olympics, Even as Spectators
item.description: The Russian hosts of the 2014 Winter Games made clear long ago they would brook no political protests at the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A police officer checked a manâs identification last week in the central train station in Sochi, Russia, amid stepped-up security for the Olympic Games.

item.title: Entrusted to Burn John Paul IIâs Notes, Cardinal Publishes Them Instead
item.description: Cardinal Stanislaw Dziwisz, who was secretary to John Paul II, has drawn criticism for defying the popeâs order in his will to destroy his notes, instead publishing them as a book.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: A British Doctorâs Death in Syria, and His Motherâs Quest for Justice
item.description: Fatima Khanâs search for justice for her son, Dr. Abbas Khan, who died in a Syrian government prison, has become a quest for public accountability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Fatima Khan, center, confronted Syrian officials in Geneva about her son, Dr. Abbas Khan.

item.title: Sports of The Times: Terrorism and Tension for Sochi, Not Sports and Joy
item.description: Never before has the pre-Olympic chatter been less about the athletes or the sports. And never before has the conversation leading up the Games been so grim.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR

item.title: U.S. Representative to Syrian Opposition Is Retiring
item.description: As the American ambassador in Damascus, Robert S. Ford was active in challenging President Bashar al-Assadâs crackdown on the emerging political opposition in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Berlin Journal: Where N.S.A. Kept Watch in Cold War, Artists Now Find Refuge
item.description: More than two decades after the United States pulled up its final cables from Field Station Berlin, the ruins of the complex still hold a mystical attraction for history buffs, artists and tourists.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti artists like James Bullough, right, and Karl Addison have been encouraged to decorate the former Field Station Berlin.

item.title: U.S. Spy Chief Says Assad Has Strengthened His Hold on Power
item.description: James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, also said that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had benefited from a deal to abandon his chemical weapons arsenal.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: German Paper Says U.S. Kept Tabs on Leader
item.description: The newspaper, SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung, reported that American intelligence services began monitoring Chancellor Gerhard SchrÃ¶der after he opposed the Bush administrationâs plan to go to war in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Pakistani Side Fails to Show Up at Taliban Peace Talks
item.description: The failure of the government representatives to appear for the talks is the latest episode in a process that has been characterized by confusion, contradiction and delays.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Members of a group chosen by the Taliban to represent them in talks with Pakistan. The talks were postponed on Tuesday.

item.title: U.N. Report Details Abuse of Children in Syrian War
item.description: The document, quietly presented to the Security Council last week, details torture, abduction and grave abuse of children by both sides in the conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
